Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Enhanced Water Recovery at the Energy-Water Nexus: Towards Water-Efficient Cooling Systems
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to save significant amounts of water at power plants and other industrial facilities, potentially saving hundreds of billions of gallons of water every year in the US. This will help reduce the water footprint of power generation and other cooling applications, reduce operating expenses for these facilities, and increase the reliability of power generation. The annual savings can be several millions of dollars per facility and the market opportunity in the US is estimated at around $4 B. Furthermore, this technology can be used for upcycling the captured water from cooling towers that use wastewater or seawater, potentially producing pure distilled water for commercial and domestic use.<br/><br/>This SBIR Phase II project proposes to advance a water capture technology for cooling tower plumes. The proposed technology uses electric fields to ionize the air around a cooling tower outlet, charge the water escaping cooling towers, and direct it toward a mesh-based collector and ultimately a collection tank on the periphery of the cooling tower. The Phase II proposal includes both systematic experimental studies to optimize the collection setup for real-world deployment, as well as material choice and durability studies. This project will optimize the design and build a pilot system, including a control panel designed for compatibility with existing systems. Data collected from the pilot installation on collection efficiency, water quality, and power consumption will be used to iterate and improve the design.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Infinite Cooling has developed a novel technology that uses electric fields to capture the water plumes leaving evaporative cooling towers and recycle it for re-use, greatly reducing the freshwater consumption of industrial processes such as power generation. The US's largest water withdrawal use is for power plants, which account for 39% of total US freshwater withdrawals, and the vast majority of this water is used for cooling. Additionally, cooling towers account for most of the water consumption of the power industry (~1 trillion gallons per year). Infinite Cooling's NSF SBIR Phase I & II Projects: Enhanced Water Recovery at the Energy-Water Nexus: Towards Water-Efficient Cooling Systems, developed a Gen 1 design of the collection technology and performed field testing on a 20MW cogeneration power plant in Phase I, followed by a Gen 2 product development cycle and a pilot deployment on a 6 MW nuclear reactor.

 

The Phase I program developed the water collection panels and custom electrodes to collect the plume escaping a cooling tower's exhaust using a lab-based water plume setup. We then installed a pilot on a 20MW power plant cooling tower cell and conducted testing on efficiency and water quality in typical operating conditions. We also estimated pressure drop effects on the customer's cooling towers and showed they were small. We finally designed and tested the viability and durability of our custom electrical insulators and other critical system-level components. We achieved all the technical goals we proposed in the application and validated our initial proof of concept.

 

In Phase II we further developed the technology to be able to collect water more efficiently in the high velocity and harsh flow conditions associated with cooling tower fans. We also developed scaling laws that help determine the size and optimal electrode geometry of our collection system. We then took the updated design of our technology and built a pilot demonstration on an operational cooling tower in the field at a 6MW nuclear reactor. We achieved the large majority of our technical goals proposed with the lab studies and field demonstration, including manufacturing a remotely controlled water collection system that was installed in one week on site. We are now piloting the technology in the industry with customers to validate the water collection efficiency and robustness of the system on several cooling tower models.
